box.text:
LG Quiz

Welcome to this short quiz.

For each question, select the answer before your time runs out!

question.text: Q1. When talking about personal finance, what does ISA stand for?

box.text:
Correct!

ISA stands for Individual Savings Account. These are tax-efficient accounts that allow you to save up to a certain amount each year.

No!

ISA stands for Individual Savings Account. These are tax-efficient accounts that allow you to save up to a certain amount each year.

question.text: Q2. What role might an ‘executor’ have within someone’s life?

option.text: A person who an individual appoints to sort out their affairs when they die
A person who files the legal documents when two people get married
A person who records deaths and births

box.text:
Correct!

Executors are the people you nominate in your will to organize your affairs when you die.

No!

Executors are the people you nominate in your will to organize your affairs when you die.

question.text: Q3. Under the government’s Help to Buy scheme, what percentage of the total property price does a person need to have for a deposit?

box.text:
Correct!

The correct answer is 5%. ‘Help to Buy‘ is a government-backed scheme to support buyers who may previously have struggled to raise a sizeable deposit.

No!

The correct answer is 5%. ‘Help to Buy‘ is a government-backed scheme to support buyers who may previously have struggled to raise a sizeable deposit.

question.text: Q4. From April 2015, how much can be deposited into an ISA (cash and/or stocks and shares) over the course of a tax year?

box.text:
Correct!

From April 2015, the limit to the amount you can save is £15,240. With an ISA you can invest up to the limit in cash, or in stocks and shares, and you can switch your savings between the two if you wish.

No!

From April 2015, the limit to the amount you can save is £15,240. With an ISA you can invest up to the limit in cash, or in stocks and shares, and you can switch your savings between the two if you wish.

question.text: Q5. How much does an average UK family (two adults, two children) spend on grocery shopping for food and non-alcoholic drinks each week?

box.text:
Correct!

According to the Office for National Statistics, average family spending on food and non-alcoholic drinks is £56.80 per week.

No!

According to the Office for National Statistics, average family spending on food and non-alcoholic drinks is £56.80 per week.

question.text: Q6. What is the average cost of a wedding in the UK?

box.text:
Correct!

A survey by ‘Brides’ magazine in 2014 calculated the average cost of a wedding at just below £25,000.

No!

A survey by ‘Brides’ magazine in 2014 calculated the average cost of a wedding at just below £25,000.

question.text: Q7. The first six weeks of Statutory Maternity Pay is equal to what percentage of a woman’s average weekly earnings before tax?

box.text:
Correct!

For the first six weeks Statutory Maternity Pay is equal to 90% of a woman’s average weekly earnings before tax.

No!

For the first six weeks Statutory Maternity Pay is equal to 90% of a woman’s average weekly earnings before tax.

question.text: Q8. At the time of the birth of a child, the father is entitled to take how long off work, as Ordinary Paternity Leave?

option.text: One or two consecutive weeks

box.text:
Correct!

A father can choose to take one or two consecutive paid weeks off work as Ordinary Paternity Leave. Expectant fathers must inform their employer no later than the end of the fifteenth week before the expected week of childbirth.

No!

A father can choose to take one or two consecutive paid weeks off work as Ordinary Paternity Leave. Expectant fathers must inform their employer no later than the end of the fifteenth week before the expected week of childbirth.

question.text: Q9. When managing your personal finances what does AER mean?

box.text:
Correct!

AER means ‘annual equivalent rate’. It is the rate of interest that you would receive if you deposited your money for a whole year.

No!

AER means ‘annual equivalent rate’. It is the rate of interest that you would receive if you deposited your money for a whole year.

question.text: Q10. To get the full state pension how long do you need to have been paying National Insurance contributions and/or receiving credits?

box.text:
Correct!

To get the full amount of state pension an individual must have paid full National Insurance contributions for 35 years, or received credits such as during periods of unemployment or when acting as a carer.

No!

To get the full amount of state pension an individual must have paid full National Insurance contributions for 35 years, or received credits such as during periods of unemployment or when acting as a carer.

question.text: Q11. When managing your personal finances what does APR mean?

box.text:
Correct!

APR means annual percentage rate. It is an interest rate that shows the true cost of borrowing in terms of interest and fees.

No!

APR means annual percentage rate. It is an interest rate that shows the true cost of borrowing in terms of interest and fees.

question.text: Q12. In which school year do all children qualify for free school meals?

option.text: Reception, Year One and Two

box.text:
Correct!

All children in reception, Years One and Two (ages four to seven) now receive free school meals. (Children from low-income families in other school years may also be eligible).

No!

All children in reception, Years One and Two (ages four to seven) now receive free school meals. (Children from low-income families in other school years may also be eligible).

question.text: Q13. From April 2015 what will be the amount of Child Benefit per week, which a family will receive for a first child (assuming neither of the parents earn more than £50,000 and therefore qualify to receive Child Benefit payments)?

box.text:
Correct!

In April 2015 this will increase from £20.50 per week for a first child to £20.70.

No!

In April 2015 this will increase from £20.50 per week for a first child to £20.70.

question.text: Q14. In April 2016, the new “flat rate” state pension will pay how much per week to those eligible?

box.text:
Correct!

From April 2016, a new “flat rate” state pension of no less than £148.40 per week will be paid to everyone eligible after this date.

No!

From April 2016, a new “flat rate” state pension of no less than £148.40 per week will be paid to everyone eligible after this date.

question.text: Q15. If you were to buy a property costing £125,000, what percentage of this cost would you have to pay as stamp duty?

box.text:
Correct!

Under the new Stamp Duty Land Tax system introduced in December 2014, buyers will pay nothing for the first £125,000. If a property costs more than this, buyers will pay 2% between £125,000 and £250,000, 5% above £250,000, and 10% above £925,001.

No!

Under the new Stamp Duty Land Tax system introduced in December 2014, buyers will pay nothing for the first £125,000. If a property costs more than this, buyers will pay 2% between £125,000 and £250,000, 5% above £250,000, and 10% above £925,001.

question.text: Q16. In 2040 what will the age of retirement be for men and women?

box.text:
Correct!

For both men and women, pension ages are rising. Both will rise to 66 years by 2020.

No!

For both men and women, pension ages are rising. Both will rise to 66 years by 2020.

question.text: Q17. If you have a Junior cash or stocks and shares ISA, what is the maximum you can contribute within one year?

box.text:
Correct!

From April 2015, the maximum annual amount that can be invested in a Junior ISA is £4,080. The start date for the year is the first day of the tax year (6 April).

No!

From April 2015, the maximum annual amount that can be invested in a Junior ISA is £4,080. The start date for the year is the first day of the tax year (6 April).

question.text: Q18. If you studied at a university in the UK as a British resident, what percentage of your income, over and above the repayment threshold, will be deducted from your salary each month to pay back you student loan?

box.text:
Correct!

UK graduates have 9% deducted from their salary, which is over and above the repayment threshold, until they have repaid their student loan.

No!

UK graduates have 9% deducted from their salary, which is over and above the repayment threshold, until they have repaid their student loan.
